This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Operation Barbarossa relied on the sole factor that the Red Army was going to be defeated in the initial months of the operation, and that the German military would then capture the country without any effective resistance.
It failed becase:
A: The germans had severely underestimated the sheer size of the Red Army.
B: The germans had severely underestimated the Red Army production capability
C: The germans had severely underestimated the Red Army ability to recover and to learn from its mistakes
D: The Germans had severely overestimated their own capabilities and conditions to conduct such a grand operation.

When Hitler said "we only need to kick in the door", he pretty perfectly described the emphasis of the entire operation.
Barbarossa was also poorly planned and was overoptimistic and did not take into account many decisive factors such as weather, hence why Barbarossa was delayed. It also did not take into account that the german forces were not mechanized to carry out the necessary pincer attacks. The majority of the army was powered by horses and infantry had to walk, leading to armored divisions constantly having to pull the breaks to let the infantry catch up, missing ample opportunity to prevent a Red army escape.

Something they also did not expect was the nature of the individual soviet soldier. It became a painful thorn for Germany that many russian soldiers refused to surrender despite being surrounded and cut off, situations western soldiers would ordinarily give up, and this added to the mounting german casualties and lost momentum.

Lend lease did not come into effect until much later and was more responsible for giving the Red Army offensive capabilities, altough they did recieve vital aid from Britain through the arctic convoys.

>I think what he was trying to highlight was that German offensive capability was still relying on horses, and that the vast majority of infantry had to walk in an operation where speed was critical to its success.
The horse-drawn logistics of Napoleon are very different from the horse-drawn logistics of Hitler. The overhwelming majority of military freight moved the vast proportion of its kilometer-tons via rail. Horses were used to move stuff from railheads to the front. Speed of the leg infantry was less of an issue. The Germans advanced faster during Barbarossa than the all mechanized/motorized Americans and British did in Italy, or in France in '44. I do not really think that the mechanized capacity means nearly as much as you seem to. It would have given the Germans more flanking capability, make actually bottling Soviet formations up easier, but it wouldn't have made annihilating the cauldrons any more so. Plus, more mechanized capacity means a heavier logistical footprint in the first place, exacerbating problem A. And the poor state of the Soviet road network made reliance on motorized and mechanized assets difficult unless the local conditions were right.

All this "muh horses" obscures the fact that Germany was pretty middle of the pack when it came to mechanization of European armies. You could have made the same argument vis a vis France, and look how that turned out. To pull off the penetration and exploitation that German doctrine relied on so much doesn't require all or even most of the army to be fast moving to pull off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14561130

>>14561130
You are an idiot. Napoleon's army (1/6th of what the Wehrmacht sent to Russia) sourced almost all of their supplies locally, because almost all of their supply needs were food and fuel. Even shot could be sourced from captured Russian stocks, and shot was much less of a need weight wise than organic stuff.

Barbarossa, on the other hand, moved far more stuff. https://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/Germany/HB/HB-6.html Check out section 4. An infantry division in combat required 1,100 metric tons of supply EVERY DAY. Barbarossa committed 153 divisions; and while not all of them were fighting every day of the operation, on any given day quite a lot of them were. German tonnage movement requirements were in the tens of thousands. Napoleon's quartermasters couldn't move anything close to that. And EVERY army of WW2 stuck to railroads whenever it could, and the ones that had to stray from them for any reason ran into problems almost immediately. Reliance on the Via Balbia made invading out of Libya and into Egypt a fucntional impossibility, and it also doomed the British to overextension and crushing defeat in the aftermath of Compass and Crusader, for all of their greater mechanization. The single biggest thing stopping the rout of German forces in France in August and September 1944 was the Transportation plan's damage to railroads that hobbled the Anglo-American forces. Soviet doctrine called for engineering units to build railroads to support advances if there weren't any nearby ones to appropriate. The Japanese offensives into China ran into immediate and remarkable difficulties once they seized the railroad networks up and down the east coast and tried to push west into far less developed territory.

>Railroads only help when you're actually near them
meant that WW2 armies stayed near railroads, at least when they wanted to concentrate into meaningfully large formations.

Ancient people weren't preconditioned to be scared of displaying penises, that only came after with Christianization.
It's also important to remember that up until very recently the term "love" was used to refer not just to romantic-sexual relationships, but also to relationships of deep respect, affection and friendship. Nowadays the non-sexual use of the term love is pretty much reserved to parent-child love, when somebody says that a mother loves her child they aren't implying incest. The 21st century man is just too much of a coomer to grasp the idea of people having deep affection towards someone they aren't fucking.

Wow, if you read any part of Marx's explanation of the LToV then you'll know what rubbish this is. He literally explains every part of these misconceptions very thoroughly and patiently. How do people think they know better than Marx when they refuse to read him?

>All the work one cares to add will not turn a mud pie into an apple tart; it remains a mud pie, value zero.
Marx himself states this. This is why he refers not to labor in general but socially necessary labor, meaning labor required to produce a gold that IS desired by somebody.

>corollary, unskillful work can easily subtract value; an untalented cook can turn wholesome dough and fresh green apples, already valuable, into an inedible mess, value zero. Conversely, a great chef can fashion of those same materials a confection of greater value than a commonplace apple tart, with no more effort than an ordinary cook uses to prepare an ordinary sweet.
He also says this directly and explains further. LToV refers to the average skill of labor to produce the same commodity. If someone is more skilled they can "do more" labor in less time than average and visa versa. In this case with skill producing higher quality it would mean they're essentially doing two different processes with two different outcomes. This is really not relevant to our world of mass produced commodity goods which Marxs is attempting to offer an explanation for.

Literally all these questions and more can be answered with the magic of opening a book and actually reading.

Inclusion is more an effect of prosperity than a cause. When you are not faced with poverty you no longer have to form close knit clans that guard the few resources you have, prosperous industrialized societies also need to trade for resources and promote people from the lower classes and so are generally more open for practical reasons.

Some level of "inclusion" is needed, a paranoid isolated society might be a bit of a disadvantage, but beyond that it doesn't really matter. Japan's Meiji restoration was accomplished with only a handful of "oyatoi gaikokujin" who usually left once their work was complete, the absolute bare minimum of "diversity", they certainly didn't need African refugees to "survive".

It is just a fantasy, one being sold due to modern sensibilities. Every historian learns about the biases of the past, but they must also be aware of the biases of the present, regardless of how they feel about it. Remember, one day this too shall pass and future historians will be judging us.

The Hebrew word for "sin", חטא, most literally means "miss". All it really means is when you try to do the right thing but fail for whatever reason.

>>14560447
Caananite fertility ritual. It's in the subset of "don't do the things those idolatrous neighbors of yours do, wouldn't want to get too friendly."

>>14560449

>>14560472
The thing about שַׁעַטְנֵז (mixing wool and linen together) is actually fairly straightforward when you remember that the official Priestly garments were made of mixed wool and linen. "Don't wear something that's reserved for the priests" is the rationale, even if it's not spelled out.

>Don't Sit Where a Menstruating Woman Has Sat
Has to do with notions of ritual purity, which while not sinful in and of itself, is something that you're generally supposed to avoid. In general, anything that used to be alive but now isn't, or could cause life but failed to, is something that you're supposed to stay away from unless you have actual business touching it (say, burying someone)

>If Your Slave Refuses Freedom Pierce Their Ear
The prototypical reason that the slave wants to stay a slave even when he can go free is that slaves are allowed to intermarry in a way that free Jews aren't. He doesn't want to leave his slave-wife that his master pushed onto him, and it seems to be some sort of mark that this is a 'sanctioned' relationship even after the term of slavery is over.

>Women Suspected of Adultery Have To Drink Dirty Water in Order To Induce Miscarriage
It's really supposed to invoke divine judgment and kill the woman if she's been unfaithful, not induce a miscarriage. It causes her bowels to burst, not her womb, at least if you believe this stuff anyway.


No idea about the behanding thing though, that one is weird.

>>14560744
>they bring a 'strange fire' into the sanctuary. Have to admit I don't know what that is, it's very vague.
It means something other than the specific incense that they were suppose to use. Burning anything other than that in that place would be a failure to observe the law, and "strange" just means it isn't the specific incense they were supposed to use. The basic point with "strange fire" is that, whatever it was, it wasn't the right thing that they were already told had to be used. See Exodus 30:8-9, 31-38.

>>14560847
There are definitely symbolic applications of a lot of the laws that involve ritual purity, which is one of the main parts of what is known as the ceremonial law. Ceremonial was one of the three main parts of the Mosaic law along with the moral law and civil law. The ceremonial law, by the way, is the part that is considered to be fulfilled in the New Testament by Christ; it includes things like dietary laws, a specific religious calendar, animal sacrifices, and anything to do with maintaining ritual purity. Whereas the moral law still applies and the civil law is still a good idea (but has to be enforced by a righteous government with courts rather than by vigilantes).

>Although Nixon never much cared for the State Department, he retained a good deal of respect for his old friend Bill Rogers and initially saw him as a counterbalance to Kissinger as a foreign policy adviser. The idea of balancing power was always something that preoccupied the president even though he always intended to be his own Secretary of State. But it was Rogers who spoiled the strategy of man-management by backing out of the philosophical debates on foreign policy that Nixon was enamored of. Nobody knew this more than Rogers's hand-picked deputy Elliot Richardson, the Undersecretary of State. As Richardson recalled, "There was something in Bill that caused him to look down on the president and his musings on geopolitics. Bill was good at advising on a specific problem, such as when the North Koreans shot down one of our planes* but he had the usual failing of lawyers who see situations as cases. He didn't seem to realize that every foreign police move is a decision into a flow. He spoke slightingly of 'all the geopolitical thinking' and turned most of the interactive discussion of the NSC over to me."

*Referring to the shootdown of an EC-121 reconnaissance plane by a North Korean SAM on April 14, 1969. Nixon wanted to retaliate by bombing one of their airfields, Rogers talked him out of it.

I thought up a small argument against image veneration myself.

1. One of their claims is that Christ's incarnation, God taking upon himself an image, means that we can show veneration to God through man-made images. But we can only show veneration through a man-made image, not worship. But Christ can be worshiped through his actual physical presence, if he were literally present. So there isn't a direct analogy between Christ's body and a statue or painting. They're necessarily in different categories.

2. If only veneration can be shown to a man-made image of Christ, this means that the only way to worship Christ is without a man-made image. You can never worship him through it or you would be committing idolatry. So the use of images requires you to show less honor to Christ than he is actually due.

Interestingly, many early Christian apologists appealed to the aniconism of the ancients in justifying Christianity. Heraclitus rejected idols as well, and Rome was well-known to have rejected all idols for the first century of its existence. It is like Romans 1 teaches, people exchange God for creation.

Numa Pompilius:
> His opinion, also, of images is very agreeable to the doctrine of Pythagoras; who conceived of the first principle of being as transcending sense and passion, invisible and incorrupt, and only to be apprehended by abstract intelligence. So Numa forbade the Romans to represent God in the form of man or beast, nor was there any painted or graven image of a deity admitted amongst them for the space of the first hundred and seventy years, all which time their temples and chapels were kept free and pure from images; to such baser objects they deemed it impious to liken the highest, and all access to God impossible, except by the pure act of the intellect.

>>14553604
Panagia may also refer to a prosphoron (Ἄρτος της Παναγίας, Ártos tēs Panagías, "Bread of the All-Holy") which is solemnly blessed in honor of the Theotokos during the Divine Liturgy (see Prosphora for details). From this loaf, a large triangle in honour of the Theotokos is cut and placed on the diskos (paten) during the Liturgy of Preparation. The remainder of the loaf is blessed over the Holy Table (altar) during the hymn Axion Estin, just before the blessing of the antidoron. The priest makes the Sign of the Cross with the Panagia over the Sacred Mysteries (consecrated Body and Blood of Christ) as he says, "Great is the name of the Holy Trinity."
https://www.liquisearch.com/panagia/blessed_bread

>Justin Martyr, et al.

Where does Justin Martyr criticize or condemn the veneration of icons?

I have seen it claimed he does so in his Hortatory Address to the Greeks, ch. 16 (https://www.newadvent.org/fathers/0129.htm) but given the context, that is a strained interpretation at best.

Likewise wrt Clement of Alexandria, if the claim rests on his remarks in the Paedagogus quoted here: https://russianicons.wordpress.com/tag/clement-of-alexandria/

Likewise Irenaeus to the extent the claim rests on Against Heresies, I, 25.6 (https://www.newadvent.org/fathers/0103125.htm), given that those remarks are plainly directed at an idolatrous practice by a gnostic group. It goes beyond the sense of the passage to infer from it a condemnation of the veneration of icons in a Christian context.

>Irenaeus in condemning the Carpocrates isn’t condemning them for having art work per se of things in heaven, earth or under the earth. He doesn’t invoke biblical language as read to prohibit all image making. Nor is there here an unconditional condemnation of veneration of images. Irenaeus doesn’t say that veneration is evil and therefore what the Carpocrates are doing is evil...

>There do seem to be three things that have warranted Irenaeus’ condemnation. First, they claim to have an image made by Pontius Pilate of Jesus. They seemingly use this to bolster their claim to apostolic authenticity.

>Second, that they set up this image of Jesus along with various philosophers... This implication seems to be that Jesus is one of many men of wisdom...

>Third, that they have other modes of honoring these images [that] are essentially the same as those found among the pagans for honoring their gods.
https://energeticprocession.wordpress.com/2010/03/31/irenaeus-and-icons/

Likewise Origen: https://desuarchive.org/his/thread/14499705/#14503601

As for Ephiphanius, he is persuasively disposed of by Papandrea, >>14557515 @ 20:20

In sum, the sources do not make out the claim.

>>14561164
Catholic doctrine is that when Adam was created, his natural state was not sufficient for him to perfectly obey the law and thus merit eternal life, so God infused with him an superadded gift of grace (donum superadditum) which, if Adam cooperated with it, would enable him to perfectly obey God. Adam failed and was cut off from this grace, and so are all of us through original sin, but we regain it through baptism.

In contrast, Protestants generally hold that Adam was created with the ability to obey God and merit eternal life as a natural ability, as simply a part of his creation. This is an integral part of Pelagianism. Protestants are not total Pelagians in that they do not extend this ability into the post-fall pre-baptismal state. But this concept, that pre-fall man had the natural ability to perfectly obey God, is Pelagian.

By sheer coincidence these places do not have rampant drug problems.

This whole debate is literally midwit atheists trying to be edgy. The thing is, even without getting into the question of God this is just pure wank from people who have never even tried to put what we know about the universe into a coherent thought.

We by definition can't know for sure if God is there or not. But let's assume he is not for the sake of agrument and stay purely in physics.

1) We have no idea how the universe really works. We might be in a many-worlds scenario. In which case infinitely many versions of you have lived, live and will live forever.

2) We have no idea what conservation of information actually does. The no-hiding theorem tells you that no information is lost to decoherence, which death is. Make of that what you will, but in principle the universe remembers everything forever and that information can be restored.

3) We don't know if the universe is cyclic, in whuch case see you again after next big bang.

4) We don't know if the infinity of time is larger than the infinity of matter and space (if either is infinite). If time is a higher order infinity then the universe will have a Poincare time (time of repeat).

4) depending on the above the universe could be ergodic and will reach every possible state infinitely many times. Meaning you will live again. In fact you will live again in such a way that that version of yourself an infinity from now will have continuity of thought to you right now.

Hurr durr we ded is such a medieval understanding of things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14543404
Despite the huge size of the complex most residents had no idea what was going on. In many ways they had it better than a lot of Poles in other parts of Poland. The huge number of SS personnel and other German settlers required servants and many residents found employment and protection that way. My grandmother was a teenage girl during the war and she became a maid for a family of German settlers who actually treated her well, giving her all sorts of luxury items for her service. On the flipside a portion of the population was expelled to make space for the camp and some residents became more aware or less complicit than others and were smuggling medicine and food inside the camp or helping forced laborers escape.
Generally speaking the public was unaware of what was going on inside the camp until the later stages of the war. From 1942 to 1944 a lot of escapees wrote reports that eventually made their way to the Home Army, then the Polish government in exile, then the Allied governments and finally the press. This increased awareness eventually led Jewish communities in the US and Britain to advocate for bombing campaigns against the camp's railway infrastructure but the only raid that actually took place was against IG Farben works at the Monowitz subcamp

>>14543443
Auschwitz II originally started off as a POW camp, but it's purpose quickly changed
It wasn't a pure extermination camp in a sense that everyone who ended up at Birkenau would be gassed, but rather it served as both a giant distribution centre for the Reich's slave labor system as well as an extermination place for those who were deemed too useless to be a slave laborer. Many people (mainly Poles) were in Birkenau only for transit purposes. Out of those who remained not all of them were killed outright as the Auschwitz complex had its own labor requirements. Inmates were used to expand the camp, guard each other, sort through people's personal belongings or for work in various subcamps. So in this sense it wasn't a pure extermination camp, but industrial killing was without a shadow of a doubt one of Birkenau's functions

>>14551050
Wooden doors can be made gas tight if constructed sturdily enough, and with a sealing material between the slats, which these doors were. The preassure differences between the inside of the room and the outside of the room would have been equal; the only gas transfer the doors would have needed to counter was from diffusion. They did not need to be pressure-sealed hatches like what you see on submarines, for example.

Keep in mind also that poison gas killes based on its concentration. Even the presence of small leaks would not have hampered operation of the gas chamber. Consider how with carbon monoxide poisoning, some people in the building can die while others in a nearby room remain unharmed.

>Did troons exist in prehistoric times?

Yes, but the societal and social view of it was so radically different that in some ways it isn't completely comparable.

For the most part any kind of mental illness, retardation, or visibly strange/eccentric behavior was often diagnosed as possession or otherwise spiritually significant. Children with Autism or Asburgers were infamous for being percieved as the babies of Trolls or Changelings that were swapped when mom wasn't looking.

When it comes to something like transgenderism or sex dysmporphia or whatever we have really no way of meanginfully inferring that from the past. What we have going on atm with trannies is extremely specific, interpersonal, and really defined within our own social bullshit. That said: there does seem to be some kind of loose context or idea of a transexual, 3rd gender, hermaphrodite, throughout history. A male that embodies female qualities, a female that embodies male qualities, etc.. This was often attributed spiritual significance and these people were quarantined into religious positions like shaman or witch doctor.

Atenism was absolutely monotheistic. The Hymn to the Aten written by Akhenaten himself makes it clear that Aten is the sole creator and driving force behind his creation.

https://youtu.be/wFfLK2pmMnw

Akehnaten was in all likelihood the first Pharaoh described in Genesis who elevated the Israelite people's into a position of power. The Pharoah who took the throne after the various succession crises following Akhenaten and Tutankhatens early deaths was Horemheb. Though he is considered to be of the same dynasty as Akhenaten, he was entirely unrelated to them. It was Horemheb who began the persecution of Atenism with the support of the old priest caste. It was Horemheb who tried to erase akhenaten from the record. This was the same Pharoah whose heart was hardened by God and tried to enslave and genocide the Israelites before they escaped.

Moses was in all likelihood among the last Atenist priests, and his name is Egyptian in origin. In his early life he had a direct relationship to the ruling family at the time.

If it isn't clear, Aten is the same God of the Bible, applied through a uniquely Egyptian lense. I can't honestly imagine listening to the Hymn to the Aten as a believer and not considering it to be inspired. Disregarding that it's probably the basis for Psalm 104, it's among the most beautiful and compelling descriptions of God's creation and how He pertains to it.

Regarding those who perceive Atenism as a pragmatic attempt at consolidating central power, and not a genuine spiritual awakening, the direct and special relationship Akehenaten claims to have with God is the exact same that was claimed by later Christian Kings, and has a scriptural basis. Akhenatens reign and edicts are absolutely consistent with what you would expect from a Christian Monarch thousands of years later. The only reason why people reject this notion is because it doesn't fit the right historical era, but nonetheless it happened.

posts.com:
>>14558997
A counterpoint I can think of is that people in each region may think differently from each other, there is no reason why God has to deliver truth the same way to each people. God could have revealed Hinduism and Buddhism to the Indian subcontinent and revealed Judaism to the Hebrews for a good reason unknown to us. There is a problem with this though, as this then implies that the truth about God's plan for the world can only be obtained a priori. At that point, there's no way to determine if your examination of religion is correct, or my proposed one.

The only way to get to one conclusion would be through tangential arguments with their own assumptions on how humanity --from the deeply personal to the grand scale of cultural-- experiences the world. One such argument to support a sort of universal "religion" or spiritual beliefs existing is the following: religions can be corrupted by the people who practice it. Take all the different denominations that Christians have; which one of these is truly the proper way to venerate and follow the teachings of Jesus? Even if one such true denomination exists: how many followers of this denomination practice the teachings correctly?

Keep in mind you are approaching this topic with a very deconstructionist mindset. With this mindset you remove many of the aspects that make religions empowering to a person. Removing the power that any institution might have over people isn't always a good thing, because removing the stability that these institution provide allows for malicious actors --like suicide cult leaders or totalitarian ideologies-- to gain the ability to control them. Stability with institutions --like religious beliefs and centers-- might be extremely difficult to correct the bad things about them, but it is also very difficult to insert horrible practices into them as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Suevi kingdom capital discovered in Spain
posts.com:
What was thought to be an Iron Age fortification, called castros, has turned out to be a late-medieval settlement, hidden in a forest, that had a 1.2-kilometre wall and around it no less than 30 towers. The towers were covered by roofs similar to those of the wall of Lugo (Galicia). It is likely that it was built during the reign of Hermericus.

The site, which has emerged under the vegetation thanks to laser photographs taken with a drone, was known as Castro Valente, dates from between the 5th and 7th centuries after Christ, and it is estimated that it could have had an area of more than ten hectares. . Its walls, which at some points have been found to be up to four meters thick, are nevertheless seriously damaged due to human action.

>What would have been the consequences of a decisive Imperial Russian victory in WW1 on the internal state and the diplomatic arrangements of Europe?
I'd suppose it'd depend on what year this decisive victory was in.
The Russians did allow the formation of the Polish National Committee and the creation of Haller's Blue Army in the West and promised to restore Polish autonomy to Congress Poland and Russia's desired territories from Germany and A-H. How much we can trust that this would be respected, is debateable. If Russia were successful, it could pose itself as the reunifier of Poland, and were it to actually respect Polish autonomy (which wasn't impossible with Nicholas II and the Duma). Their goals in regards with these areas, were to weaken Germany overall, and end A-H aspirations in the Balkans.
Regarding the Ottomans, in March 1915, the Russians had secured per the Constantinople Agreement the area in yellow around the Straits, and by April 1916 per the Sazonov–Paléologue Agreement, the yellow in Anatolia (which they'd practically already occupied in their entirety). Many Armenians hailed this as their liberation, evidenced by the vast amount of Armenian volunteers, however nothing was explicitly promised to them.

>The U.S. Supreme Court issued its historic Brown v. Board of Education, 347 U.S. 483, on May 17, 1954. Tied to the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, the decision declared all laws establishing segregated schools to be unconstitutional, and it called for the desegregation of all schools throughout the nation.[1] After the decision, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) attempted to register black students in previously all-white schools in cities throughout the South. In Little Rock, Arkansas, the school board agreed to comply with the high court's ruling. Virgil Blossom, the Superintendent of Schools, submitted a plan of gradual integration to the school board on May 24, 1955, which the board unanimously approved. The plan would be implemented during the fall of the 1957 school year, which would begin in September 1957.

>When integration began on September 4, 1957, the Arkansas National Guard was called in to "preserve the peace". Originally at orders of the governor, they were meant to prevent the black students from entering due to claims that there was "imminent danger of tumult, riot and breach of peace" at the integration. However, President Eisenhower issued Executive Order 10730, which federalized the Arkansas National Guard and ordered them to support the integration on September 23 of that year, after which they protected the African American students.[3]
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_Rock_Nine

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I actually sympathise with vegans and their softhearted dislike of suffering and death. The sad part is when you realise that raising grain and even fruit entails a lot of killing, of insects and birds.

You could make an appeal for some kind of advanced hydroponic farming system that doesn’t exist, but bottom line is that keeping billions of humans alive as it stands today involves the callous shooting to death of birds on a staggering scale to keep grain available for human consumption. Birds are incapable or unwilling to respect humans’ desire to raise grain for their exclusive consumption, so they are killed to prevent them from taking it.

There are plenty of good reasons to oppose modern intensive livestock farming operations, though. Mostly on environmental grounds. And even if in some quantitative way an argument could be made that the hardship of slaughterhouse workers and the suffering of animals in such a fast paced environment is insignificant on a global or cosmic scale, on a human level I can still see why you might find it distasteful and not want to play a part in it.

Still, at the end of the day, to eat, we essentially all kill, vegan, vegetarian, and meat eater alike. Making the case for principled philosophical vegetarianism, the sort that condemns also picturesque Eskimo, African tribesman, and Highland villager who are really just eking a living from the land however they can just the same as the urban consumer, who is making an active choice, seems weak.

The Ottomans were unable to industrialize (ask me about the industrial output of the ottoman empire prior to the first world war) for the same reasons Russia couldn't. However, Russia was slightly more industrialized due to Peter The Great, who enacted the reforms Turks needed to also do. The Ottomans didn't even take notice of the problem until the disastrous Crimean War - a war the Ottomans won, although with significant western assistance. With Napoleon in France, who enacted similar reforms to industrialize France in relation to the UK and Germany, this began a series of events that would kill both Empires in the same way they started: an extremely violent genocidal war that, ultimately, would be decided by western powers. By this point the west had formalized all their internal relations into the Peace of Westphalia, which prevented the Napoleonic Wars from wrecking a similar havoc on Western internal relations.

Going back to the start: The Roman Empire had similar conflict resolution mechanisms enabling pan-European and some pan-Asiatic trade. Most of this was done through marine shipping and waterways. The breakdown of such systems in the west permitted Ottomans increased, and more aggressive, expansion of such trade in the east (usually overland but not entirely) making them wealthy. Many were still farmers, herdsmen, fishermen, etc but a larger middle class developed and remained until discovery of the new world. The Ottomans were consistently wealthy until ~1600. Which, not coincidentally, was around the same time the first English colony at Jamestown, Virginia was planned and setup in 1607. By this point all Western powers had navies whereas the Ottomans and Russians didn't. Industrial development resulting from this would prove to be hugely consequential over the next 400 years.

Not him but Jason Goodwin (son of a British occultist and journalist) published the greatest book all about the Empire designed for the English language. >The USA still has yet to match picrel
I agree that measuring space programs by their unique accomplishments is a better metric. The Moon landing is the most significant and high profile example of this, but it's not the only one. For example, the US has sent probes to every single planet in the solar system, including/even Pluto, while the Soviets only ever explored Venus and Mars. American exploration of Mars is also undeniably superior to the Soviet program. The Soviets had one "successful" landing, before losing communications with the lander some 20 seconds later. In comparison, the first American lander was operational for some 6 years and American rovers have been active on the Martian surface for the past few decades.

All in all, the US has an edge in the exploration of every major celestial body in the solar system besides Venus. But it's not like being the only ones to explore Mercury, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, and all of their respective moons is something that should be considered noteworthy.

There were persistant revolts up until about 1070, particularly in the north, and also by the sons of Harold Godwinson, which the Conqueror spent a lot of time brutally putting down. In 1075 the Rebellion of the Three Earls broke out led by some survivors from the Old English order, but most Englishmen were on the king’s side and it was put down without much effort. There was a massacre at Gateshead in Northumberland in 1080 of the sitting bishop and his Norman knightly retainers because of the latter’s violence. This was punished by William too, in brutal fashion.

By this point the English were resigned to the Normans, although still clearly resentful, since their equivalent to Alfred the Great who rallied against England's premature destruction by the vikings - Harold Godwinson - was killed at Hastings, and Edward the Confessor had already prepared the state for Norman dominance prior to his death. His upbringing in Normandy did lend some credence to the idea of a Norman king upholding the legacy of the Confessor against the usurpation of Godwinson, and to be fair, William did retain much of the essence of the Anglo-Saxon state and its traditions.

posts.com:
Lowell Amos, a General Motors production manager, was a "Bluebeard" killer, a man who marries and murders multiple wives in succession, usually for financial gain. Four people, including his own mother, died at his hands over a 15 year period before he was finally apprehended. It began when Amos's first wife Saundra, a schoolteacher, had passed away suddenly one winter morning in 1979. Lowell found her dead in the bathroom of their Anderson, Indiana home and claimed to investigators that she had fallen and hit her head on the bathroom counter after drinking a glass of wine mixed with a sedative. No specific cause of death was determined, and Lowell received $350,000 from his wife's life insurance policy.

Soon afterwards, Lowell married his longtime mistress Carolyn Traylor. Carolyn's friends recalled that she had frequent rows with her husband over the huge insurance payouts he took on her. In 1988, after nearly a decade together, she told Lowell she was leaving him if he didn't cancel the insurance policies. Lowell agreed to a divorce, packed his bags, and went to live with his 76 year old mother Mary. On July 17, Mary Amos was hospitalized after suffering dizzy spells and mental confusion. Doctors were unable to determine a cause, but she regained her senses after a few days and was discharged and sent home.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Carolyn made regular phone calls to her mother-in-law to check how she was doing, but on July 26 Lowell picked up the phone instead and reported the sad news that Mary had died earlier that day. She rushed to the house to find her husband packing his bags and throwing them hastily into his car. Lowell explained that he wanted to get out of there quickly before anyone found out that a 45 year old man was living with his mother. Mary's death was ruled age-related and due to natural causes, and no further investigation was done. He inherited $1 million from her estate.

Surprised at pleased at Lowell's newfound wealth, Carolyn agreed to accept him back into her life. Unfortunately, she lasted just nine more months. On April 6, 1989, Lowell called 911 to report that his wife of a decade was dead. He claimed Carolyn was in the bathroom drying her hair with a blow dryer. He brought her a glass of wine, and later on went to check on her and found her laying dead in the bathtub. Lowell said he thought she accidentally electrocuted herself with the hair dryer, but the cause of death was listed as "Indeterminant." The wine glass she had supposedly been drinking from was found washed and stacked in the kitchen. Carolyn was laid to rest at the age of 46 in Chesterfield, Indiana's Bronneberg Cemetery.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not long after Carolyn's death, Lowell remarried to the much younger Roberta Wagner. He retired from managing the Anderson, Indiana plant around this time and opened his own consulting firm in Detroit. On December 10, 1994, the two were attending a GM executive party at the Atheneum Hotel in the Motor City. They retired to their room around 4:30 in the morning. A couple hours later, Lowell called Bert Crabtree, another GM manager, and looked distraught. Crabtree and a friend named Daniel Porcasi, went to the room where Lowell announced that Robert had died in an accident. He said he had to clean up the room before police got there, and told Porcasi to take his sport coat.

The next morning, Porcasi was heading home when he casually peeped inside the breast pocket of the coat. Inside was a small black leather case which contained a syringe with no needle. An extremely bad-smelling washcloth was jammed inside it. Repulsed by this discovery, Porcasi closed it back up. He gave the coat back to Amos the next day, who claimed the syringe was for a saline substance.

Police meanwhile were talking to Amos about the discovery of Roberta's body. They arrived at the hotel to find him shirtless, a cigarette in one hand and a towel in the other, as he remarked "She's in the other room, cold as a fish." He told them the two had had a cocaine-fueled sex party the night of December 10-11 and he awoke to find Roberta dead. Amos claimed his wife had a sinus problem and was not able to snort the coke, instead she "took it inside her." Indeed there was cocaine sprinkled on the bed linen and under the mattress. Forensic examination of Roberta found the cause of death to be acute cocaine poisoning, a whopping 15 times higher than the minimum fatal dosage.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There was cocaine inside Roberta's vagina, which apparently confirmed Lowell's claim that she couldn't snort the stuff and had to use alternative means of ingesting it. But there was no way this alone could account for the massive amount of the drug found in her system, in fact so much that her body had not even metabolized much of it.

Something was definitely amiss here. A cocaine overdose would cause violent convulsions, and it seemed unbelievable that Lowell could sleep through such an event, or that he himself could sleep after ingesting a large quality of it. The bedsheets and pillow had unusual streaks, as if someone had been trying to wash them off. The pillow case had traces of makeup on it, although Roberta was not found to be wearing any, and it also bore lipstick imprints and tooth marks, as if someone had had their face pressed into it in an attempt to smother them.

Lowell Amos certainly didn't act like a distraught spouse when, just two days after Roberta died, he took two different women on dinner dates and had sex with both of them. Once the news of Roberta's death was publicized, several other women came forward to report that Amos had dated them and they were sure they'd been drugged and date raped.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Investigation into his background found out the inexplicable deaths of two previous wives and his mother. It was not until November 5, 1995, nearly a year after Roberta died, that there was enough probable cause to arrest Lowell on charges of first degree murder using a toxic substance. He was picked up in Las Vegas, which he'd packed his bags for shortly after Roberta died.

Although Lowell never confessed to anything, the prosecution at his 1996 murder trial brought up his history of women dying around him for large insurance payouts. Roberta didn't have any large nest egg worth having, but she had been threatening to leave him not long before her death. Lowell likely bumped her off out of simple anger rather than monetary gain. From the forensic evidence, it was believed that Lowell gave his wife wine mixed with sedatives, and then used the syringe Dan Porcasi found in his coat pocket (although this syringe was never found, having disappeared shortly after Amos reclaimed the coat from Porcasi) to inject cocaine mixed with water into her vagina. No charges were filed in the deaths of Saundra, Carolyn, and Mary Amos.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Shirley Wagner, the mother of Roberta, vehemently denied that her daughter was a drug user. Mrs. Wagner had known Lowell Amos pretty well as she used to work at the Anderson GM plant that he served as a manager in and she remembered him being an excellent worker and "extremely intelligent." But she was leery about her daughter's decision to marry him, as she knew he had two previous wives who died under mysterious circumstances. "I don't know why he killed her," Shirley remarked. "There was no financial motive for him. He must have really hated her to want to do that."

Lowell Amos was sentenced to life in prison with no possibility of parole. He passed away in Michigan's Lakeland Correctional Facility on January 5, 2022, one day after celebrating his 79th birthday.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14560070
The original base text is the received text, for both Hebrew, Syriac-Aramaic and Greek (New Testament) and the most prominent English translation of this is the KJV. Unfortunately all other modern versions that I know of, that claim to be based on the received text, have at least some corrupting influences in them. I'm not sure whether it's intentional or not, but there you go.

>closeness to the earliest texts
Closeness to the earliest text, specifically being based on the original text, is what's most important. So you got that right. Before you look at translations make sure you haven't accidentally chosen a non-original text, because there's no point in using a translation based on these. That would only help you understand how certain people have tried to change what the Bible originally was, rather than the Bible itself properly speaking.
>accuracy
This is probably I would agree the second most important thing, because you want the translation to accurately reflect whatever the base text you use. In English the KJV does this job well. The only real reason some people stopped using it is because they were convinced that we have lost the original text by some scholars, and were sold a bill of goods to buy their version instead, and then dozens of different base texts were created based on some very deviated manuscripts that don't even agree with each other as much as they differ, which is very different than the situation you have with the received text, which is very uniform within its text type manuscripts. The main differences within the received text line are spelling differences and some other minor things in the Greek grammar that would translate to the same thing regardless. Other text types like the Alexandrian vary wildly, and modern constructions like the NA / UBS are artificial in that they really represent no line of texts at all (pure interpolations in Acts 16:12 for example), although they are based mostly on Alexandrian readings still.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14560070
>Current choice is the Orthodox Study Bible
The OSB is based on the NKJV in the New Testament. In the Old Testament it is a translation of the Greek Septuagint; however it deviates from the Greek in some places such as Genesis 5. The Septuagint says "167 years" in Genesis 5:25 and "188 years" in Genesis 5:28, for example. This is significant because it means Methuselah outlived the flood (by 14 years) according to this variant. However the Hebrew version has the numbers 187 and 182 in these two places, resulting in Methuselah dying the same year as the flood.

The OSB follows the Hebrew in these verses of Genesis, avoiding this issue. Although if you look at other translations of the Septuagint like the Brenton Septuagint of 1844, or a Greek edition, you will see the years 167 and 188 in these two verses. These versions at least stay true to their Greek source here, even if it contains an apparent error.

Among missing prophecies in the OSB, there is the messianic prophecy in Psalm 2:12, since the word "Son" (referring to the Son of God) is omitted. The OSB (and LXX) is also missing another major messianic prophecy in Isaiah 9:6–

Compare the two translations:
"For unto us a child is born, unto us a son is given: and the government shall be upon his shoulder: and his name shall be called Wonderful, Counseller, The mighty God, The everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace."
- Isaiah 9:6 KJV

>"For unto us a Child is born, unto us a Son is given; and the government will be upon His shoulder. His name will be called the Angel of Great Counsel, for I shall bring peace upon the rulers, peace and health by Him."
- Orthodox Study Bible (2008)

Notice the difference: The Septuagint does not include any mention of the title in the second part of Isaiah 9:6. I could name several more messianic prophecies also missing in the Septuagint, for instance Jeremiah 33:15, Daniel 9:26, Hosea 11:1, Habakkuk 3:13, Zephaniah 3:17, Haggai 2:7; all of these are found in the KJV.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14561226
Generally speaking with the Septuagint in the Old Testament, about 1/8 of the book of Jeremiah is missing, including the entire second half of chapter 33. In the book of Proverbs, there are drastic changes to the verse counts, resulting in about thirty entire Proverbs missing, by my count. This is a conservative estimate on my part as many more are changed nearly to the point of being unrecognizable. There are at least thirty proverbs in the LXX that have absolutely no mention whatsoever, where they can be found in the Hebrew-based Bibles like the KJV. For instance the Septuagint– and by extension the OSB– is missing the entire verses of Proverbs 15:31, Proverbs 16:1, 3-4, 6-9, Proverbs 18:23-24, and Proverbs 19:1-2, 7, just to name a dozen or so.

Another issue with the Septuagint is with apparent New Testament synchronizations. Since the version we have was edited by Origen, it was possible that some of the changes (that he is known to have made) would include when the Old Testament text was harmonized with the New Testament to make it match. The most egregious example might be in Genesis 46:27 and Exodus 1:5, where the number 70 was changed to 75, in order to match the tally given by Stephen in Acts chapter 7. The only problem is that the text in Deuteronomy 10:22 still says 70 in the Greek, while it should have been changed to 75 (!) as it was in the first two passages, to remain consistent. There is also no reason to change the number from 70 to 75, in Genesis 46:27 and Exodus 1:5 in the first place, since the groups of people being mentioned are not exactly the same. In Acts we have mentioned the 75 people whom Joseph invited into Egypt, which included his brothers' wives, but not himself or Ephraim and Manasseh. But in Genesis the number of people who comprised the 70 people includes Joseph and his two sons, but the wives are NOT mentioned within this group (not of Jacob's house), bringing the number down to 70.

Hope some of these details helped.

>>14558035
Well, it's not my work, but the book is a collection of conversion stories, including a number of atheist/agnostic conversions.

The value of such, at least for some, is that the reader is able to, as it were, get inside the conversion process -- which is often rather mysterious. It is a way of approaching the "convert me" question outside of a dry logical proof.

People come to belief in different ways. For instance, a man named Whittaker Chambers, a convinced atheist who was once quite famous as a Soviet spy, experienced an epiphany while holding his infant daughter:
>My eye came to rest on the delicate convolutions of her ear -- those intricate, perfect ears. The thought passed through my mind: No, those ears were not created by any chance coming together of atoms in nature... They could have been created only by immense design.

Now, from my perspective, Chambers experienced God's grace at the moment.

And, interestingly, God's grace is something you are in a position to be proactive about. Thus, you can say to God, "Convince me."

That is, you can pray, to the God who may or may not exist. And this is an approach that I can recommend from my own experience, because I tried this, and it did work for me.

Ask for guidance and light. Ask for the grace of faith -- to understand, to see the truth that you cannot now see. Trust that God is good when you pray for these things... which can be a difficult thing to do, to be quite honest. But it's important. Because it may take time; it took a few years in my case for a gradual dawning of understanding to take place.

But to pray, even on a contingent basis, and then to be patient and to trust, is a kind of faith, and one that, I believe, God will reward. For He'll work with you if you'll work with Him. "Draw near to God, and he will draw near to you" James 4:8.

Indeed, there's a thing called prevenient grace. It may well be at work in you already, perhaps it is what inspired you to make this post.

This series of videos lays out the evidence for the Resurrection. They run to a little over two hours:

Check it out. The evidence is much stronger than many people realize.

If you prefer, there are several books that set out what amounts to the same argument. The longest of these, and the one with the strongest academic pedigree, is N.T. Wright, The Resurrection of the Son of God.

Essentially the same argument is made in two short books which, I think, complement each other. I highly recommend them both.

The better written of the two is Michael Green, Was Jesus Said He Was? It's out of print, but there are inexpensive used copies on Amazon and elsewhere.

A more detailed exposition of the evidence is made in Josh McDowell, More than a Carpenter.

I remind you that you have repeatedly said, "Convince me." You have asked to be persuaded. Prayer is one such mode for achieving understanding -- for that is what occurs through prayer. So, if you really meant it when you said, "Convince me," then you should pray -- or know that by not praying, you are deliberately closing yourself off to a mode of understanding, of coming to know the truth of God's existence.

Which is not far off, which is much closer than you may think. "For in Him we live and move and have our being." Acts 17:28. Prayer is not an argument, but it is an invitation to God to reveal Himself, to convince you. "Draw near to God, and he will draw near to you" James 4:8.

posts.com:
Here's a survival question, which house would you rather live in? The correct answer is the one on the left because it's made out of nice, cool mud and has a straw roof, not the concrete house on the right with the tin roof.

(That is, if both houses are in the desert like this.) The one on the left will be nice and cool inside, while the one on the right will be 150~F inside and you won't havee electricity. It's an analogy for a bigger issue, the reason Africa got fucked up after colonialism is because the colonial structures -- the "European" style capital port cities -- were not adapted to their environment and collapsed once the metropole stopped propping them up. All this sophisticated stuff that we take for granted requires a lot of people to run, and if they go away, the systems collapse.

But the mud-hut society is quite sustainable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
OP
Just at a basic level of intuition, have you never had the experience of something feeling true and false at the same time?
Like when you see through an optical illusion? Or when your foot falls asleep and it's your foot but not your foot?
With illusions we might try to explain away the paradoxical sensation scientifically but nevertheless it still feels paradoxical. I think you are hoping that there is some trick to the Trinity that lets you make sense of the paradoxical feeling.

But suppose there are paradoxes that are paradoxical feeling and can't be explained away. These paradoxes are just brute facts. There is nothing more to say about them or explain.

Also, there is an air of circularity
>How is it possible to be separate but the same at the same time?

People who reject the Trinity often proceed through this type of argument,
1) If doctrine of the Trinity is true, then it is not contradictory
2) The doctrine of the Trinity is contradictory.
3) Hence, the law of non-contradiction entails that the Trinity is false.
How could we ever hope to persuade you if you are starting from a point of reference where the law of non-contradiction applies to all propositions?

The point here is two fold. First, the Trinity IS paradoxical and accordingly FEELS paradoxical and thus the intuition that you cannot understand it isn't necessarily ironclad evidence that it is false. Second, a logical argument against the Trinity that assumes the law of non-contradiction isn't as ironclad of argument as you might think because it is circular.

Instead, I'd suggest you appraise your broader metaphysical, epistemic, and theological commitments as a whole to see if the doctrine of the Trinity fits into your holistic view of things.

Although the universal and particular exist in every genus, nevertheless, in a certain special way, the individual belongs to the genus of substance. For substance is individualized by itself; whereas the accidents are individualized by the subject, which is the substance; since this particular whiteness is called "this," because it exists in this particular subject. And so it is reasonable that the individuals of the genus substance should have a special name of their own; for they are called "hypostases," or first substances.

Further still, in a more special and perfect way, the particular and the individual are found in the rational substances which have dominion over their own actions; and which are not only made to act, like others; but which can act of themselves; for actions belong to singulars. Therefore also the individuals of the rational nature have a special name even among other substances; and this name is "person."

Thus the term "individual substance" is placed in the definition of person, as signifying the singular in the genus of substance; and the term "rational nature" is added, as signifying the singular in rational substances.

(Summa Theologica, q.29)

Some persons, however, find a difficulty in this faith; when they hear that the Father is God, and the Son God, and the Holy Spirit God, and yet that this Trinity is not three Gods, but one God; and they ask how they are to understand this: especially when it is said that the Trinity works indivisibly in everything that God works, and yet that a certain voice of the Father spoke, which is not the voice of the Son; and that none except the Son was born in the flesh, and suffered, and rose again, and ascended into heaven; and that none except the Holy Spirit came in the form of a dove. They wish to understand how the Trinity uttered that voice which was only of the Father; and how the same Trinity created that flesh in which the Son only was born of the Virgin; and how the very same Trinity itself wrought that form of a dove, in which the Holy Spirit only appeared. Yet, otherwise, the Trinity does not work indivisibly, but the Father does some things, the Son other things, and the Holy Spirit yet others: or else, if they do some things together, some severally, then the Trinity is not indivisible. It is a difficulty, too, to them, in what manner the Holy Spirit is in the Trinity, whom neither the Father nor the Son, nor both, have begotten, although He is the Spirit both of the Father and of the Son. Since, then, men weary us with asking such questions, let us unfold to them, as we are able, whatever wisdom God's gift has bestowed upon our weakness on this subject; neither let us go on our way with consuming envy. Should we say that we are not accustomed to think about such things, it would not be true; yet if we acknowledge that such subjects commonly dwell in our thoughts, carried away as we are by the love of investigating the truth, then they require of us, by the law of charity, to make known to them what we have herein been able to find out.

posts.com:
John Arnold and John Plath, a pair of cousins, were execution victims #14 and #15 in South Carolina in the modern era of capital punishment for the torture-murder of a black woman in the 1970s. The duo, both born in York, Pennsylvania in 1955, had lengthy rap sheets and a combined 30 arrests between them, everything from theft to arson to making threatening phone calls to receiving stolen property to involuntary manslaughter, and more. Needless to say, Arnold and Plath were the last people anyone, male or female, would want to run into.

On Wednesday, April 12, 1978, Betty Jean Gardner, a 33 year old single black mother, was attempting to thumb a ride near Beaufort to get to her father's farm on St. Helena, Island. A green Pontiac Ventura pulled up to her. Inside were Arnold, Plath, their girlfriends Carol Ullman and Cindy Sheets, ages 11 and 17, respectively, and two dogs. The group was heading to the beach and the Pontiac belonged to some friends of theirs, a US Marine and his wife. Betty Gardner accepted their offer of a ride. What she didn't know was that Arnold was a fugitive and had fled from a halfway house in Huntingdon, Pennsylvania while out on furlough. They drove down to the end of a dirt road and left Gardner off there. At this point, Arnold suggested killing her. When asked why, he said "Because I hate niggers."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
They went back and asked Gardner if she wanted another ride. She got back in the Pontiac whereupon Sheets started pummeling her with her fists. Arnold drove to a wooded area of St. Helena Island and Gardner was ordered out of the car and told to undress. They told her she wasn't going anywhere and started beating and pummeling her. Gardner was forced to perform oral sex on Arnold and Plath, and then perform cunnilingus on Sheets. Arnold strangled Gardner with the belt from his pants, but when that didn't work he decided to use it to hang her from a tree. He tried using some old clothing to construct a noose, but decided it wouldn't support her weight.

Next Plath tried to cut Gardner's throat with a broken glass bottle, but that didn't work either so they simply choked her with the belt until she stopped moving. The three urinated and defecated on the body and carved "KKK" into her chest, an apparent red herring designed to throw police off. The group then dispersed and went their separate ways, with Arnold and Plath returning to Pennsylvania. When Betty Gardner failed to show up at her father's farm, he called police. Betty's brother, the last person to see her alive, told police he saw her getting into a green Pontiac.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Nothing happened in the case for over a month when a detective spotted the Pontiac by accident. The US Marine owner said that he'd loaned it to John Arnold and John Plath on April 12. The two were arrested in York, Pennsylvania while Carol Ullman and Cindy Sheets were also taken into custody. Arnold and Plath were charged with first degree murder and kidnapping, and the former also with statutory rape as Ullman was under South Carolina's age of consent. Sheets and her attorneys struck a plea bargain where the 17 year old would not face any charges in exchange for testifying against Arnold and Plath. She showed police where Gardner's body had been dumped. It was discovered on June 27, eleven weeks after the murder, and was in poor condition from the hot, humid South Carolina climate; Betty was only identified through dental records. The cause of death was listed as stabbing and blunt force head trauma; strangulation was not ruled out, but the decomposition of the body made it impossible to say with certainty.

Arnold and Plath both maintained their innocence. As they caused considerable trouble, including attempted escapes, in the Beaufort County jail, they were moved to the more secure state penitentary in Columbia. The two men were tried in Beaufort County Superior Court in February 1979. Cindy Sheets and Carol Ullman testified for the prosecution and described the graphic events in detail. Sheets said Arnold was a convinced racist, and the murder was racially motivated. The two were quickly found guilty and sentenced to death. Cindy Sheets spent one month in jail as an accessory to the crime and was released. No charges were filed against Carol Ullman.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: John Arnold was executed via lethal injection on March 6, 1998, a month shy of the 20th anniversary of the murder. John Plath followed him on July 10. Both denied any culpability to the end. They were some of the rare instances in the United States of capital punishment being applied for a white on black homicide. As of 2022, just 21 persons have been executed for a white on black murder. When Arnold was executed in 1998, one hundred and thirteen persons had been executed for a black on white murder. After Arnold's execution, the executive director of the ACLU for South Carolina, Steve Bates, commented on the disparity in executions by the race of defendants and victims, as well as his belief in racism in the judicial system. Bates stated that Arnold's execution was the one exception to the rule.
